body: Also tested with **9.0.0-preview.1.24128.4** and **8.0.3** versions, same queries and results.

Confirmed.

Our byte[] representation inside JSON is base64; since SqlServerByteArrayTypeMapping uses our standard JsonByteArrayReaderWriter, everything works well when we're serializing the entire document (SaveChanges) or deserializing the entire document (load the entire JSON document).

But when a byte[] is queried as a JSON scalar, we use JSON_VALUE() and apply a type conversion (`CAST(JSON_VALUE([u].[Vault], '$.PasswordHash') AS varbinary(max))`), but SQL Server's conversion to `varbinary(max)` doesn't work with base64, but rather with SQL Server's specific format for binary data. Note that OPENJSON with WITH *does* do base64.

We knew about all this when implementing the primitive collection support in 8.0 - see #30981 and #31261; in #31261 we even blocked byte[] usage in contexts where ordering needs to be preserved, and so OPENJSON with WITH cannot be used. However, we forgot the non-collection case where simple JSON_VALUE() is used, which suffers from the same problem.

Concrete next steps IMHO are to block usage of JSON_VALUE() for varbinary (including possible patching) - the current situation causes data corruption. Longer-term, the solution here would be to switch to using OPENJSON for simple property access - with CROSS APPLY - instead of JSON_VALUE() (this is #30981).
Oh, I was searching in the issues in the wrong way. Thank you for explaining! :)
Keeping this issue for now tracking fixing this for binary specifically - for using OPENJSON for other types (e.g. `nvarchar(max)` we can keep using #30981.

issue.title: Transform JSON_VALUE() to OPENJSON/WITH for binary/varbinary

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
This transforms JSON_VALUE() into OPENJSON() in postprocessing for JSON binary/varbinary properties, applying base64 decoding to the data coming out of JSON and properly converting it to SQL Server binary/varbinary. I can't say I'm happy with SQL Server making us jump through all these hoops, but at least our query infrastructure now makes it pretty nice and easy to do this kind of stuff...

Note that this PR only handles binary/varbinary; other cases where we may want to transform JSON_VALUE() to OPENJSON() (e.g. `nvarchar(max)`) aren't handled and are still tracked by #30981.

Closes #33435

/cc @maumar @cincuranet

issue.title: Consider using OPENJSON for our JSON scalar access

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Issues that have been approved but are not scheduled a specific release.

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
When using owned JSON entities, we currently use JSON_VALUE to extract scalars out of them. Since JSON_VALUE always returns nvarchar(4000), we apply a cast to the results based on the model type. For example:

```c#
_ = await ctx.Blogs.Where(b => b.Details.Foo == 8).ToArrayAsync();
```

... translates to:

```sql
SELECT [b].[Id], [b].[Name], JSON_QUERY([b].[Details],'$')
FROM [Blogs] AS [b]
WHERE CAST(JSON_VALUE([b].[Details],'$.Foo') AS int) = 8
```

There are issues with this translation:

* Binary data (varbinary) cannot be extracted in this way: the standard JSON representation for binary data is base64, but a regular relational CAST doesn't do that ([see comment](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/30727#issuecomment-1561765456)). OPENJSON with WITH does decode base64 data, since it applies a JSON-specific conversion. Binary data specifically is covered by [#33435](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/33435).
    * On the other hand, spatial data cannot be converted with OPENJSON with WITH, only with a regular cast. The same may be true of hierarchyid.
    * We need to go through all supported SQL Server types
* JSON_VALUE returns null for strings larger than 4000 (or can throw in strict mode) (see [#29477](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/29477)).
* There's good reason to believe that this translation is inefficient compared to OPENJSON with WITH, where the query supplies more information to SQL Server.
    * See [this](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/13617#issuecomment-1556016939) and [this](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/13617#issuecomment-1561125154). Both these comments are about OPENJSON without WITH (and not about JSON_VALUE), and are in the context of primitive collections; but the same principles should hold here as well - needs to be confirmed.

The alternative translation would be to use OPENJSON with WITH instead:

```sql
SELECT [b].[Id], [b].[Name], JSON_QUERY([b].[Details],'$')
FROM [Blogs] AS [b]
CROSS APPLY OPENJSON([b].[Details]) WITH ([Foo] int '$.Foo') AS [d]
WHERE [d].[Foo] = 8
```

In other words, every scalar access adds a CROSS APPLY to an OPENJSON invocation, applying the JSON conversion with WITH.

When the property being extracted is known to be a short string in the model (fitting in nvarchar(4000)), we could keep the current JSON_VALUE translation. When the type being extracted is incompatible with OPENJSON with WITH (e.g. geometry), we could do OPENJSON without WITH and then apply a relational cast (we should avoid JSON_VALUE still it truncates).

Note: consider the indexability of this technique, compared to JSON_VALUE (with computed columns)
